creator: mhuffman@ca.ibm.com
text:
When 2 <element>s are declared having the same global <complexType> and 1 of 
them is in the other's substitutionGroup, an error is produced by the parser 
when trying to do a valid substitution.  Here's a valid example:

xc3_3v13.xml
============
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<svi:Root xmlns:xsi         ="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
          xmlns:svi         ="http://www.Test.org/3_3v"
          xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.Test.org/3_3v
                              xc3_3v13.xsd">

<svi:Child1 Name="John"/>
<svi:Child2 Name="Jane"/>

</svi:Root>

xc3_3v13.xsd
============
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<schema xmlns          ="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
        xmlns:sv       ="http://www.Test.org/3_3v"
        targetNamespace="http://www.Test.org/3_3v">

<complexType name="childType">
  <sequence>
    <element name="GrandChild" type="string" minOccurs="0"/>
  </sequence>
  <attribute name="Name" type="string"/>
</complexType>

<element name="Child1" type="sv:childType"/>
<element name="Child2" type="sv:childType" substitutionGroup="sv:Child1"/>

<element name="Root">
  <complexType>
    <sequence>
      <element ref="sv:Child1" maxOccurs="2"/>
    </sequence>
  </complexType>
</element>

</schema>
we didn't consider the case that the two types are the same
